metadata.title: Acute limb ischemia in patients with COVID-19 pneumonia

body_text.text: Acute lower extremity ischemia (ALI) is a common vascular emergency.1 The etiology of ALI may maybe multifactorial with thrombotic occlusion generally occurring in the setting of a previously-treated arterial segment or associated with atherosclerotic arterial disease.2 Patients with hypercoagulable states are known to be at risk of native arterial thrombosis which is one of the most challenging of ALI scenarios.3 A recent analysis of a large database showed improved overall in-hospital mortality and early amputation rates, but in the context of a hypercoagulable state, surgical decision-making and related clinical outcomes have been poorly reported.1

The novel coronavirus pneumonia (COVID-19) pandemic has affected the globe with Italy leading many reports of incidence and mortalities. In the past few weeks, really only March 2020, the number of patients with the COVID-19 skyrocketed in northern Italy especially in the Lombardia region and is speculated to be due to the older population. Recently published papers have described the clinical characteristics and overall outcomes of COVID-19 patients with the impact on the healthcare system.4 Two studies have reported associated coagulopathy disorders. These reports have highlighted a co-existing hypercoagulable state in patients with COVID-19, which may be associated with higher mortality.5
,
6 A sudden and significant increase of COVID-19 infected patients presenting with ALI has been noted at our institutions with the viral spread. The aim of our study is to describe the incidence and characteristics, as well as clinical outcomes, of patients presenting and treated for ALI during COVID-19 pandemic in an Italian tertiary care hospital.

Open surgical interventions were performed in the operating room under loco-regional or local anesthesia and intravenous sedation, using 80U/Kg of intravenous heparin at arterial clamping, and routine antibiotic prophylaxis. All patients received oxygen support: at the moment of this analysis, no patient required preemptive intubation due to COVID-19 related pneumonia. In cases of aorto-iliac or femoro-popliteal occlusion, a standard groin incision was used for expose of the femoral bifurcation. We selectively used a below-the-knee incision to expose the popliteal artery in patients with isolated popliteal-tibial occlusion. Upper limb ischemia was treated through direct open brachial artery exposure. Thromboembolectomy was performed using standard embolectomy catheters (Le Maitre®; Burlington – MA; USA) sized according to the location of the occlusion. In all cases, completion angiography was performed through the surgical access (Figure 2
C). Tibial arteries and/or forearm vessels were approached selectively in cases of distal occlusion. Fasciotomies was not performed on a routine basis. In latter cases, especially in those with a typical aspect of desert foot, our protocol has been augmented with intra-arterial loco-regional thrombolysis using alteplase (Actilyse® – Boehringer Ingelheim Italia S.p.A.; Milan – Italy) at a ratio of 20 mg/20 minutes. Postoperative anti-thrombotic regimen has been standardized with the most recent patients receiving anticoagulation regimen consisting of continuous intravenous heparin infusions. In case of <80% basal level of anti-thrombin III (AT-III), 500 units of AT-III was infused ten minutes before starting with continuous intravenous heparin to reach 2.5 aPTT (activated partial thromboplastin time). Thrombi retrieved from each patient were sent for histology evaluation (Figure 2). Postoperative surveillance was performed with physical examination every hour coupled with a full blood panel every eight hours. Transfusions of packed red blood cells were given only if the hemoglobin level decreased to <8g/dL. An infectious disease specialist evaluated each patient regularly during the entire hospitalization in order to optimize the type, dosage and duration of antibiotic and anti-retroviral therapy. At discharge, all patients were given enoxaparin sodium injections (Clexane – Sanofi S.p.A.; Milan – Italy) for home use at a therapeutic dosage. Follow-up and surveillance imaging will include clinical visits with ankle-brachial index and duplex ultrasound examination at 1, 6, and 12 months, and then yearly. Any change in examination or ankle-brachial index or suspicion loss of patency will be confirmed with duplex ultrasound and CT-A.

The clinical status was defined according to the Rutherford classification system.6 Medical comorbidity grading and operative outcomes were defined according to recommended reporting standards and best practice documents of the Society for Vascular Surgery (SVS) and European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS).6
,
7 Complications were recorded as being perioperative (<30 days) or late (>1 month) and classified as graft-related or procedure-related. Complications were described as mild (when resolved spontaneously or with nominal intervention, did not prolong hospital stay or did not cause permanent disability), moderate (need for significant intervention, prolongation of hospitalization for >24 hours, a minor amputation, or association with minor disability that does not interfere with normal daily activity), or severe (necessitates a major surgical, medical, or endovascular intervention and includes prolonged convalescence, major amputation, permanent disability, or death). Major amputations were classified as transfemoral or transtibial; minor amputations were considered any toe or forefoot amputation and were not considered in the analysis of freedom from amputation. Successful revascularization of the treated segment was defined in the absence of early (<30 days) re-occlusion or persistent forefoot ischemia, or major amputation or death ≤24 hours. Primary outcomes were successful revascularization, early (<30 days) and late survival, postoperative (<30 days) complications, and limb salvage at the last clinical evaluation available lasting at least seven days after revascularization.
body_text.section: Definition and primary outcomes ::: Materials and Methods

body_text.text: Clinical data were prospectively recorded and tabulated in Microsoft Excel (Microsoft Corp, Redmond, Wash) database: statistical analysis was performed with SPSS, release 25.0 for Windows (IBM SPSS Inc.; Chicago – ILL; USA). Continuous variables were tested for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk's test. Variables that were normally distributed are presented as means ±standard deviation (SD) and their range; otherwise they are presented as median and interquartile range (IQR). Categorical variables are presented as frequencies and percentages. Categorical variables were analyzed using a chi-square test or Fisher's exact test where necessary. An independent samples Student's T-test was used for continuous variables. A Wilcoxon signed-rank test was used to evaluate the difference in blood tests before and after revascularization. All reported P values are 2-sided; a P value <0.05 is considered significant.

We evaluated 20 patients with ALI who had COVID-19 pneumonia. During the same period, 3 patients were treated for ALI being tested negative for COVID-19. For historical context, during 2019, only 27 (4.3%) of 630 arterial interventions were performed for ALI. If we consider the same calendar period (January-March) in 2020, the incidence rate of patients presenting with ALI in 2020 was significantly higher [23/141 (16.3%) vs. 3/163 (1.8%), P < 0.001)]. The current study cohort includes 11 patients who presented to our Emergency Department and 9 who were transferred from other hospitals. There were 18 (90%) male and 2 female patients. The mean age was 75 years ± 9 (range, 62-95). Demographics, comorbidities and risk factors, are reported in Table 1
. Briefly, all patients had already presented with COVID-19 pneumonia as documented by preoperative CT scan. All patients with medical history of atrial fibrillation (n = 5, 25%) were on oral anticoagulation at admission. Among those patients with previous peripheral vascular intervention (n = 4, 20%), occluded graft was not determined as the only/leading reason of occlusion causing ALI. The mean arterial PO2 was 66 mmHg ± 21 (range, 31-110). The median interval time of transfer from the outside hospital was 120 minutes (IQR, 67-168.7). Acute limb ischemia stage at admission was Rutherford’s stage IIa in 2 (10%) patient, IIb in 15 (75%) patients, and stage III in 3 (15%) patients. The mean preoperative SVS score 6 ± 4 (range, 1-15).

Three (15%) patients did not undergo revascularization. These patients had severe COVID-19 related pneumonia and intervention was not carried out due to their moribund condition: mean 47mmHg PO2, mean SVS score of 8.3, and Rutherford stage III (2 patients). Operative treatment was performed in 17 (85%) patients. Local anesthesia with sedation was used in 15 (88.2%) patients, and loco-regional anesthesia in 2 (11.8%). Thromboembolectomy was performed for infrainguinal occlusion in 11 (64.7%) patients, bilateral aorto-iliac occlusion in 3 (17.6%) patients, and upper limb occlusion in 1 (5.9%) patient. Below-the-knee femoro-popliteal bypass was performed in 2 (11.8%). Selective tibial vessels thrombectomy was performed in 5 (29.4%), and additional intraoperative thrombolysis in 4 (23.5%) patients. Adjunctive procedures were aorto-iliac kissing stents (n = 2) because of not detachable residual clots, femoral endarterectomy (n = 1), below-the-knee popliteal PTA (n = 1). At completion angiography, no critical chronic atherosclerotic obstructive lesion was observed, as well as no anastomotic defects were observed in the surgical/endovascular graft already implanted. Postoperatively, all patients received systemic anticoagulation with a weight-adjusted therapeutic regimen using low molecular weight heparin (n = 11) or intravenous heparin infusion (n = 6). No bleeding complications were observed. Of note, all cases had macroscopic evidence of black and grey striped thrombus. Thrombus was sent for histologic examination.

There were 8 (40%) in-hospital mortalities with causes of death reported in Table 2
. Age was significantly higher in those who died (years, 81 ± 10 vs. 71 ± 5 years, P = 0.008) with mortality rate in those aged ≥ 80 years significantly higher than less than 80 years of age (83% vs. 21.4%, P = 0.018). At univariate analysis, no comorbidity or risk factors was associated with mortality. Preoperative SVS score (7.7 ± 4.9 vs. 4.6 ± 3, P = 0.091) and preoperative CPK value (12056 vs. 3437, P = 0.083) tended to be associated with mortality albeit not statistically. In contrast, at univariate analysis the use of intravenous heparin was significantly associated with survival (0% vs. 57.1, P = 0.042).

Revascularization was successful in 12/17 (70.6%) patients. During hospitalization, 2/15 (13%) patients underwent reintervention because of a recurrent thrombotic occlusion of the treated arterial segment on postoperative day 1st and 2nd. No ipsilateral deep venous thrombosis was detected in patients with desert foot or in those who delevoped recurrent thrombotic occlusion. Overall, limb salvage was obtained in 14/15 (93.3%) patients: major amputation was needed in 1 patient who was an 81 years old man transferred to our institution 450 minutes after symptom onset and in whom, the attempted revascularization was unsuccessful. Univariate analysis showed no significant differences between those who had successful revascularization and those did not, neither in terms of comorbidities nor in terms of SVS risk profile (P = 0.739). The presence of COVID-19 related pneumonia was not significantly associated with successful revascularization (45.4% vs. 66.7%, P = 0.620). In contrast, preoperative PO2 was significantly lower in those who had not successful revascularization (mmHg, 46 ± 8 vs. 76 ± 17, P = 0.004). Although successful revascularization was not significantly associated with the postoperative use of intravenous heparin (64.7% vs. 83.3%, P = 0.622), no patients receiving intravenous heparin required reintervention.

This preliminary observational study has major limitations. First, the small number of patients included. Secondly, the period of inclusion and observation is short. Third, we lack robust data on coagulation parameters to evaluate the eventual persistent status of hypercoagulability. Lastly, the significantly higher number of patients treated for ALI may reflect the increased population which we are serving from the start of this infective emergency, as well as according to the suggested surgical priorities indicated by governmental disposition.

In our preliminary experience of COVID-19 widespread in Lombardia region, the number of interventions for ALI has significantly increased. This higher incidence and the high failure rate due to unsuccessful revascularization seems to support a marked hypercoagulable status in these infected patients, a process which could be triggered by viral infection. These observations, as well as the findings coming from experimental models, have led us to strengthen our treatment protocol by mainly focusing on the use of intravenous heparin. The addition of heparin could seem to increase treatment effectiveness and most importantly has been associated with better survival.

FIGREF0.text: Figure 1: Preoperative computed tomography scan of a 66-years old man with COVID-19 pneumonia suffering from acute limb ischemia. Transverse and coronal thin-section scans show extensive ground-glass opacities of both lungs.

FIGREF1.text: Figure 2: Preoperative computed tomography angiography with volume rendering 3D reconstruction (A) showing the presence of intraluminal thrombus (B) at the infrarenal aorta (white arrow), and the total occlusion of the popliteal segment (white dotted arrows) and the absence of tibial vessels, bilaterally.Final completion angiography showing a morphological aspect of “desert foot” after large amount of thrombus removal for femoro-popliteal-tibial occlusion that needed selective thrombectomy of all tibial vessels, bilaterally.

FIGREF2.text: Figure 3: Thrombus specimen after aorto-iliac-femoro-popliteal thrombectomy and bilateral selective tibial artery thrombectomy.
